output.conclusion: By the end of this course, you will have a strong understanding of explainable recommendation techniques and be able to apply them to improve the transparency and trustworthiness of your recommendation systems.
output.introduction: This course provides an intermediate-level introduction to explainable recommendations. We will explore various techniques for generating explanations for recommendations, focusing on methods that enhance transparency and user trust. This course assumes a basic understanding of machine learning and recommender systems.

chapters.description: Overview of Explainable AI and its importance. Motivations for explainable recommendations: Trust, Transparency, and User Control. Different types of explanations: Ante-hoc vs. Post-hoc, Local vs. Global.
Why explainability is crucial in recommender systems. Impact of explanations on user satisfaction and trust. Challenges specific to explainable recommendations.
Generating explanations based on association rules. Example: 'Recommended because users who liked X also liked Y'. Advantages and limitations of rule-based approaches.
Explaining recommendations based on item features. Example: 'Recommended because it's a Sci-Fi movie with similar actors to what you've watched before'. Techniques for extracting relevant features.
Explaining recommendations based on similar users. Example: 'Recommended because users like you also liked this'. Techniques for identifying similar users and items.
Using latent factors to generate explanations. Example: 'Recommended because it aligns with your preference for action and adventure'. Visualizing latent factors.

modules.moduleTitle: Explanation Methods: Collaborative Filtering and Matrix Factorization

chapters.description: Using attention weights to highlight relevant features or interactions. Applying attention to neural recommendation models. Interpreting attention weights as explanations.
Using causal models to identify the true causes of recommendations. Addressing confounding factors. Counterfactual explanations: 'Would you have liked this item if...?'.
Metrics for evaluating the quality of explanations: Accuracy, Comprehensibility, Trustworthiness. User studies for evaluating explanations.
Techniques for visualizing explanations: Feature importance plots, Interaction graphs. Designing effective visualizations for different types of explanations.
Case studies of explainable recommendation systems. Integrating explanations into user interfaces. Best practices for designing explainable recommendation systems.
Addressing potential biases in explanations. Ensuring fairness and transparency. Mitigating the risk of manipulation.
